database.label: Knowledgebase
database.tooltip: Knowledgebases synthesise data from a number of sources including published literature, databases and other types of data sources. They often have a manual curation component. They can be considered secondary databases as they store data derived from primary sources.

database.label: Repository
database.tooltip: Repositories allow the submission, storage of and access to data (datasets, software, materials and other digital objects) and include (multi)disciplinary, generalist, project, data type and institutional repositories.

database.label: Hybrid Knowledgebase/Repository
database.tooltip: Knowledgebases and Repositories are databases that have features of both knowledgebases and repositories.

standard.label: Model and format
standard.tooltip: Describes resources that provide a common structure for all data of a given experimental type. They are structured representations of information from a conceptual model or schema, which enables (syntactic) interoperability among systems. These formats are often created using base formats such as XML, CSV or RDF.

standard.label: Metric
standard.tooltip: Criteria to assess some aspect of a digital resource, for example - but not limited to - its discoverability.

standard.label: Terminology artefact
standard.tooltip: Controlled vocabularies or ontologies that describe the meaning, or semantics, of data and metadata. They provide a method of annotating data in a way that is useful for humans and comprehensible by computers, and allow for better collation and searching of the data.

standard.label: Reporting guideline
standard.tooltip: Provides a checklist for the minimal descriptive content required to evaluate, interpret and disseminate an experiment. Defining a common set of metadata to guide researchers in reporting scientific context is important for data repositories, journals and funders. Often reporting guidelines do not have a literal checklist, but are rather presented as a document stating required and optional attributes.

standard.label: Identifier schema
standard.tooltip: Identifier schemas (e.g. URLs, pURLs, DOIs) describe publicly-available identifiers from a central registry.

policy.label: Journal
policy.tooltip: A journal data policy describes those formats and/or databases that are recommended for use for authors submitting a manuscript to that journal. Such resources may be described either explicitly or in a more general way.

policy.label: Journal publisher
policy.tooltip: Sometimes the publisher of a stable of journals has overarching data policies that apply to all journals.

policy.label: Society
policy.tooltip: Particular societies (e.g. standards development organisations) often provide data policies so that researchers wishing to align with society best practices have a concrete data policy they can implement.

policy.label: Project
policy.tooltip: Particular projects may have a data policy that describes those resources that must be used by project members. Please note that this policy type should only be used for large-scale projects.

policy.label: Institution
policy.tooltip: This is a relatively new policy type for FAIRsharing. Please use this to describe your institution's (e.g. a university's) data policy for its employees and, sometimes, collaborators.

policy.label: Funder
policy.tooltip: Funders often have strict requirements about the type of databases or standards that they wish their grantees to use.
